trial_identification.studytitle: Electromyographic study of facial muscles in nasal and oral vicious and obstructive -breathing children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Electromyography of facial muscles in nasal and oral (vicious and obstructive) breathing children

interventions.interventions: Surface electromyography (EMG) exam of facial muscles (masseter, temporal and upper and lower mouth orbicular muscles during rest and isommetry of labial and masticatory muscles. The duration of the EMG was about an hour. Each signal was recorded during 10 seconds.
interventions.comparator: The data were compared between the control group (nasal breathing children) and study group (mouth breathing children)

primaryOutcome.outcome: The outcomes showed that the EMG activity did not differ between nasal and mouth breathers. The respiratory mode did not interfere in the muscular activity behavior.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The evaluation of the children was performed during three months and the outocomes was obtained after this period.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: children with nasal or mouth (vicious or obstructive) breathing diagnosed by otorhinolaryngologist
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: children with signals and symptoms of neurological disease or syndrome, previus facial surgery or malformation, to be in speech therapy or orthodontics treatment.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Federal University of Santa Maria, Department of Speech Therapy, campus, km 09 highway, Camobi, Santa Maria, RS, CEP 97119000

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Federal University of Santa Maria, Department of Speech Therapy, campus, km 09 highway, Camobi, Santa Maria, RS, CEP 97119000

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Federal University of Santa Maria, Department of Speech Therapy, campus, km 09 highway, Camobi, Santa Maria, RS, CEP 97119000

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose of the study was to verify the muscular activity of facial muscles of nasal and mouth breathing children, and compare them, in order to improve the diagnosis and therapeutic intervention for this problem.
